This... isn't right

there really are single wavelengths which are "violet". 405nm is a popular laser wavelength, and it is violet. A lot of entry-level college physics courses have a lab where students observe the emission spectra of noble gases. helium has two violet bands.

Violet wavelengths stimulate both the "red" and "blue" cone cells. How? The use of quotes around the colors is a hint: the "red" cone cell is weakly sensitive to violet light. So is the "green" cone, in fact.

I'm finding mixed messages on the "red" cone's precise sensitivity to violet light. Some sources say it has a second peak in violet. Others say it is roughly the same sensitivity as green there. I think people might be mixing graphs of cone response with graphs on how cameras and rendering engines should map wavelengths to the RGB color space. The latter has a highly pronounced red peak in violet, while the former usually has little to no peak in both red and green. It's hard to be sure, though.

A typical camera does not capture the violet band of a rainbow because it does not properly map the response of violet light for the "red" cone when producing its "red" channel. They show an extra-long blue band.

crossover between primary and supernumerary rainbow rings does happen, but a violet band is visible even in artificial rainbows (diffraction grating, prism, putting your thumb on a garden hose) where there is little (for the hose) or no (for the prism and the grating) supernumerary ring.

There are a great many purples which cannot be created with a single wavelength, but it's not every purple.

sources:
https://youtu.be/HauiF_AQUIY (laser example, cone cell response [strong-red-peak graph], camera deficiency [cameras with and without it])
https://www.unm.edu/~toolson/human_cone_response.htm (cone cell response [slight-red-green-peak graph])
https://pages.jh.edu/~rschlei1/Photographic/violet/violet.html (cone cell response [no-peak graph])
https://astronomy.nmsu.edu/geas/lectures/lecture19/slide02.html (helium emission spectrum example)

Magenta AKA purple looks more like violet than any other color we can reproduce with RGB primaries. That's because the cone cells in your retina which are the most sensitive to red (the L cells) also have a secondary response in the violet. So both S (blue) and L (red) cones are stimulated by violet more than M (green) ones. What other color stimulates both blue and red? Purple. Hence violet is closer to purple even without supernumerary bows.

It's still wrong. your eyes do perceive violet as "purplish" even when there's no red around. I've heard that shorter wavelengths do actually mildly activate the long wavelength (red) cones in your eyes. It could also be the fact that very short wavelengths activate the shortest wavelength cones in your retinas without the usual level of activation of the mid wavelength cones that are also activated by blue light.

(normal human eyes have 3 different cones with different wavelengths, but they're not a simple Red,Green,Blue additive as they're often described.)

This video is wrong. Human eyes do see violet at the end of any spectrum, regardless of any rainbow duplication taking place. The human eye detects color through 3 types of cone cells, each sensitive to deferent wavelengths. The cone cell that is sensitive to the wavelength we call red, is actually sensitive to both the long wavelengths just above inferred, and to the short wavelengths just bellow ultraviolet. This is why we see a light tint of violet at the end of the spectrum. It’s because the cone cells in our eyes that actually detect red light, are also a little bit sensitive to the blue light at the end of the spectrum. Refractions in rainbows may increase this effect, but it not why we see violet at the end of a rainbow

In Russian, a slightly different situation with rainbow colors, because we have words for "dark blue" (синий/siniy)

(red, orange, yellow, green, light blue, blue, purple)

This is the most stupid unscientific video ever.  First, the supernumerary discs do not look anything like what you are posting.  They occur at very specific angles.  And you dont see the discs internally within the main rainbow, only externally.  Second, the colors are switched like a mirror in other rings.  In other words, even if the disc formed within the main rainbow disc, the colors would be inverted.  Go watch Walter Lewin's lecture on this subject and fix your video.  You are so wrong in so many ways.  The purple you see in a rainbow is violet - a spectral color

This video is objectively wrong. I have a violet laser (which is a single wavelength of light) and it looks, surprise surprise, purple (specifically violet). The reason some pictures of rainbows and prisms don't have the violet is because some cameras use crappy perceptual maps and just map that region to be a blue color instead of mapping it to the blue-red combination that, for whatever reason, we persceive as similar. Please do some research before perpetuating a myth that actively teaches people the wrong thing.
Source: have a Violet laser and have a hobby doing color science.

May I point out that what they teach children is ROYGBIV ( Red, Orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, and Vilot). And we can seperate colors by primary, secondary, and tertiary. In the rainbow we have all the primary colors (red, yellow, blue) and all of the secondary colors (Orange, green, vilot). But we have indigo in the rainbow, a tertiary color, technically I shouldn't belong in the rainbow if we are not including lime green and cyan. Therefore, when a child ask me the colors of the rainbow I don't include indigo.

Why the rainbow is the gay pride flag symbol:
Gather around kids and let me tell you the story of the first gay power couple.
One day water was lonely because all the creatures he held would splash around and have fun together but water had no one.

Sun was doing his regular shifts around the world and made his way around, bored and solitary as usual.

Water had watched sun on suns morning jog for several days until one day he decided to meet sun. In the afternoon, using all his might, water flew up as a Geyser to meet sun and chat.
They had a wonderful time but soon Sun had to leave. Water was sad but promised to see Sun again.

The next day water went up to see Sun again he waited for Sun joyful to have a love like all the creatures in the sea.
Finally when Sun arrived water went up to meet him.
Everyday they would meet up, and whenever they did, a beautiful thing was created. You guessed it, the rainbow! One day water desperately wanted to be with sun up close. So he created the biggest geyser ever and made his way to sun.

Today you can still see them when it rains with the sun out.

Good point, but the fact is that the red cones spectral sensitivity have a little peak in violet region. That makes violet more reddish than deep blue.
Even so, the spectral sensitivity of red channel in cameras don't have this peak and the pure violet seems blue in photos.
Of course, the rest of the colors beetwin violet and red in the "color circle" ther aren't in the pure spectral colors, these are mixtures two or more pure spectral colors.

I must say, I disagree. There are spectral colours with wavelengths of 420-430 and they are not blue. The sensitivity of the red photoreceptor in the human eye increases at this point slightly so it makes sene, we percive this colour as something like violett or purple. Something slightly more red then "pure blue". I am quite sure, that tehe sensitivity of the red receptors vary from one to another so everybody might see a different blue or violett and it wouldn't suprise me, if men, who are usually a bit weaker in colour seeing have more problems to recognize spectral violett. I have seen the emission spoectruzm of potassium trough a prism spectrometer and I have seen a violett line in the 400-420 nm area. Some of my costudents were not able to see it. So my conclusion is, there is violett at the end of a rainbow, but not everyone can see ist.

Just want to ad a little info about the number of colors in rainbow (mostly for society). It depends on a language. For example in Russian there are two different names for the color which is called “blue” in English (have to mention that these are the basic color categories). There is “синий” and it describes this deep blue ocean color or these geniuses t-shirts, something like royal blue. And there is also “голубой” which describes a light-blue or a bright-blue color of the sky. So in Russian rainbow has 7 colors: red, orange, yellow, green, light-blue, deep-blue and purple.
And! There are languages with another basic color categories. For example wobé has just 3 names. (I think that Vox have a video about it)

False. There are a number of reasons for all of the inaccurate, primarily scientific, explanations in this video. It's actually scratched down to historical explanations. At the time, violets were actually blue, because purple was more of a magenta color. Purple dye was collected from a rare mollusk, which is why purple dye was to valuable at the time. The reason why newton didn't stop at "red orange yellow green blue" is because he too saw a difference in hue. He really only saw six colors but, because of religious beliefs, could not use six, as it was considered an "unholy number", so he bumped it up to seven by adding indigo in there.

Right before he started on the fact that purple can be perceived in rainbows in the sky, a question popped into my head.
If roses are red and violets are blue,
Then why do we refer to purple as... blue?
All the purple crayons and pencils and markers Crayola make (that I've seen), along with many other brands, have this habit of saying, "Purple (Violet)", or something along those lines. Why? Maybe because the label violet used for close rainbows was blue, but when viewed normally as an arch of light formed from the light of the sun (or moon at times), it shows up as purple, so we all associated violet with blue?
If someone could find the etymology of the word violet and maybe also the point where it shifted from blue to purple, I would love to hear about it! Thank you!!!

No there is no purple in the rainbow but violet and purple look identical to the human eye. This is because we only have red green and blue color sensing cells. Yellow is sensed by input from the red and green cells and violet (and purple) are sensed by input from the red and blue cells. So violet is VIOLET, not blue.

Your explanation for the purplish appearance of violet in rainbows is interesting and seems to make sense, except that I for one actually perceive violet as purple when using a prism, as well as when viewing certain pigments that appear as pure blue in cameras and when viewing through sunglasses that block "high-energy blue" (which is basically violet). Therefore I think that something else is going on involving the convergence of the responsivity curves of the "blue" (S) and "red" (L) visual pigments, in conjunction with human visual processing and perception. The following sources would seem to suggest something along those lines:
http://gene.bio.jhu.edu/violet/violet.html
http://math.ucr.edu/home/baez/physics/General/BlueSky/blue_sky.html

And here is a sample discussion that brings up similar hypotheses:
http://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/40763/why-does-light-of-high-frequency-appear-violet

This video is totally wrong about violet. The author has apparently never seen a violet LED or a violet laser, or repeated Newton's simple experiment in a darkened room. Sure Newton's "blue" may be our cyan and Newton's "indigo" may be our blue, but violet really is a (non-overlapping) rainbow color that looks different from blue (to people with normal color vision). Violet cannot be shown on a standard computer screen, but its best RGB approximation is maximum blue plus half as much red. "Violets are blue" is poetic license, purely to rhyme with "you".

I see "purple"/violet in rainbows without trouble. It is right around 400 nm. I think the real explanation here comes down to rods and cones in the human eye. We have three types of cone in our eye - red, green, and blue and they are sensitive to light of roughly long, medium, and short wavelength respectively. S cones appear far LESS frequently than M or L cones, meaning we have less ability to perceive color in the shorter wavelengths and thus the purple color looks washed out or overwhelmed by the other colors. Depending on the exact distribution in an individual's eye, the purple may be more or less apparent. In fact, roughly 95% of all cones are M or L, leaving just 5% of space for S cones. Additionally, the concentration changes at the fovea, where most of our detail vision is concentrated, with the ratio of S cones dropping even further.

This videos explanation of color do not fit with the most accepted theory of human color perception.

Violet light certainly does exist. However, there is no pure red in the visible spectrum. Human, sensation and perception of color is produced through the opponent process where red never exists without also containing either yellow or blue. The "red" end of the spectrum appears somewhat more red than bright orange, but it indeed contains some yellow, so it's actually (to a degree) orange. At the other end of the visible spectrum red exists again, in this case, in combination with blue. So we get the cokor violet.

We can only produce red by negating either yellow or blue using a green value in oposition (on the y axis ) to the value of yellow or blue depending on whether red is produced from orange or violet light. But when green is added red becomes desaturated with gray. Thus, there is no such color as pure red.

You should never go by what you see on an image if you're talking about rainbows: the violet of a rainbow lays way beyond the RGB color triangle, which is way smaller than the visual spectrum, and will ALWAYS be shown as blue by a camera or monitor, because this is the closest color you can get with RGB! Violet actually does lie in the visual spectrum, at 380-450 nanometers, but you can never capture this on an image. This is probably also where the confusion originates: if you try to show violet on a computer screen, you do need red to make your eyes believe that they are looking at violet, but in a rainbow, there's actually no red there.

If you want to see actual violet for yourself, just look at the rainbow that you see when you hold a cd in daylight (artificial light most often doesn't contain a lot of violet and blue).

Actually, violet is NOT blue. The spectrum does NOT end in blue either. The long cones in your eyes have two response peaks. The violet end of the spectrum stimulates both long and short cones without stimulating the medium cones. The sensation is very like purple.

Now, if you're old enough for the lenses in your eyes to have yellowed, you may not be able to see spectral violet any more.
Also, most cameras don't have a second response peak in their red filter, and fail utterly to render spectral violet as anything but blue.

It's seven notes in most scales derived from the ancient greek/mideval european tradition. Harmonic minor scales have a small thirds distance between the 6th and 7th note and that still doesn't magically add extra numbers of notes to the scale. Melodic minor scales, because they are slightly different on the way up as on the way down ends up having 9 different notes within the octave again because that is how that scale is constructed, not because of the absolute distance between X and Y. A scale is defined as the number of notes and relationships of pitch within an octave. A whole-note scale, where the distance between every note is equal have 6 different notes, not 5. Blues-scales are kind of pentatonic, but with the addition of three optional "blue" notes for a total of 8 different notes within an octave. You can easily find the number 5 though. The 5 available notes left out of a major scale form a pentatonic scale. The 5th note in both major and minor scales are the dominant and the most consonant (as opposed to dissonant) interval. A perfect 5th vibrates at a frequency exactly 50% higher than the tonic and so on.

Violet light is at the end of the visible light spectra, so regardless, it would be faint for cameras and faint for our eyes.

The reason I'd heard for purple looking red was that our red and green cones, while both insensitive to blue light, aren't equally insensitive. Green cones respond less to blue light than red ones do. So, while violet isn't any more red than blue is, our retinas read it as "less green," and the other channels take up the slack.

We can't just say that there are only six colors in the rainbow, or seven, or any number. The spectrum can be divided into any number of colors, 12 or 24, for example. In 24 divisions there are colors that could be called 'purple' and 'pink'. We could count the three primary and the three secondary colors of light, making six total in this set, but we'd have to specify that these are the colors we are counting. If so, these would be red, yellow, green, cyan, blue, magenta.

I have to admit I didn't really thought about and interference effects in rainbow until I saw a pretty obvious supernumerary rainbow quite recently. Anyway, I don't when people argue whether there are 6 or 7 colors in the rainbow. Because what their are arguing about is language, not about the physical reality. Rainbow is a spectrum. However, the language seems to affect our perception and we tend to see color stripes where there are none.

the rainbow can kind of funky if one has anomalous color vision:
the natural rainbow and the rainbow as it exists on a computer are different.

in particular, in my case, the point where sky-blue / cyan should be on a rainbow is "different".

for example:
there is a band like:
Red, Orange, Yellow, Green (vision and monitors seem to fully agree here);
then it blends from green to "something";
then it blends from this "something" over to blue/violet.

this "something" color, however, is absent on monitors, and in its place is cyan.
but, it isn't really like a normal color, it is "weirder" (it is sort of like if retinal rivalry were a color, rapidly flashing and pulsing between several different colors, as seemingly eyes can't agree to exactly what color it is supposed to be, so it mostly just looks like "some unnamed weird color").

(ADD: before I had called it "green-grey", but "green/violet" seems like a better name, because it is like the color one would see if they can see both green and violet at the same time...).


though, to some extent, I see this "flashing" effect with blues in-general, most strongly where cyan should be (it rapidly flashes between green and gray with traces of violet, but tends towards olivine), and also with some forms of blue/indigo (which rapidly flicker between blue/indigo and black, *). (but yeah, weird green/violet flashing != cyan...).

and, in general, the colors on monitors and in magazines look a bit off from what I see IRL, but the colors on monitors are also a bit more "stable".


*: though, this effect seems to be confirmed with cameras. where my eyes see the flickering blue, cameras either see flat black, or black with a noise pattern of blue sparklies. then there are bug-zappers and "super blue" fluorescent tubes, which are very bright IRL yet apparently largely invisible to cameras.


then again, my mom and maternal grandma had tritanomaly/tritanopia though (AKA: "blue/yellow colorblindness").

This discussion here is going to make bad temper in the comments section, so I'm taking the lead in cleaning up this mess of personal opinion:
Calling the last note 'Si' or 'Ti' is just a matter of cultural context, but both represent the exact same thing.
So in germany for instance, 'Si' stands for the tone G#, when you're going upwards chromatically starting from C like this: Do (C) - Di (C#) - Re (D) - Ri (D#) ...... So (G) - Si (G#) - La (A) - Li (A#) - Ti (B) - Do. Downwards, or in a 'b' scale it would be like: Do - Ra - Re - Me - Mi - Fa - Se - So - Le - La - Te - Ti - Do. In my opinion, this system makes totally sense, so I keep on using it. But in different countries there'll be different practises of doing it. Like americans still using the imperial system, though it's totally counterintuitive and outdated. Peace folks, I hope I could help you with this.

I believe that interference isn't the main reason for seeing purple light at the end of rainbows. Any white light spectrum, has kind of "red" feeling is at the high-frequency end, and it is so strong that can't have been caused by an interference. I think it's simply about our eyes. Just take a look at the link below. You'll likely notice that the red cells (the red line) has two parts. The low-frequency part (right side in the image) causes a "red" feeling in colors like yellow, orange and of course, red itself. But the high-frequency part (at the left), causes a "red" feeling in high-frequency colors.
